Well, it's the same old Rocky premise: Current champ is seen as a fake by the public and fights Rocky in hopes of gaining the respect he thinks he deserves. However, it's a premise that works and true Rocky fans embrace time and again. Sure, I wasn't completely happy with the ending, and at times Rocky gets carried away with his moronic one liners. But, Stallone delivered what he promised: a sweet goodbye from an old friend

To put things in perspective, when the original "Rocky" came out, my wife was still three years away from being born.  That's 30 years Stallone has been playing this Rocky Balboa.  I grew up with the first two films on endless TV reruns and saw the later ones in the theater.  My nostalgia-fueled anticipation for tonight's premiere was akin to the thrill I felt for the final "Lord of the Rings" movie, or for "Superman Returns", or even for the misbegotten Chronicles of Narnia movie last year.  Literally I've been waiting decades to see this movie.  "Rocky V" bombed when I was still in high school and I was hoping Rocky would get one last chance to knock out evil boxers with ridiculous ring nicknames.

My advice is that you'll need to see this movie in a packed theater, as I did.  I can't imagine it would have the same effect on the small screen when you're alone with a much smaller crowd.  In many ways, the best part of this film was the spontaneous call-and-response from the audience I was with, two storeys beneath 3rd Avenue.  People shouted famous "Rocky" catchphrases at the screen seconds before the famous fanfare started playing.  "I pity the fool!", "I will break you!", "If he dies, he dies!", and, of course, "Mickey!!"

Once all the pre-movie nostalgia was out of the way... it was time for more nostalgia.  Wisely or not, Stallone (who wrote and directed) soaked the first half of the script in nostalgia so deep for the first, small-scale "Rocky", that significant screen time was devoted to characters who hadn't appeared since the original's second reel.  I had to explain to my wife who Spider Rico was, and why Rocky needed him in his inner circle by the end of the movie.  Also great to see the return Duke, Apollo Creed's old trainer, although most of Tony Burton's lines appear to have been looped in post-production.

The main problem with "Rocky Balboa" early on is Stallone's concept of dialogue.  Just about every character in this movie delivers a loud speech about motivation and glory and drive and passion.  Rocky's defense of his application for a boxing permit to the State athletic commission (after 20 years of retirement) is particularly ludicrous, although Stallone must think it's going to cap off the montage for his Lifetime Achievement Oscar.

Once the nostalgia and flashbacks clears out and the plot settles in, the film picks up steam.  Antonio Tarver does a decent job as Mason "The Line" Dixon, the brazen young champ at odds with the boxing establishment.  Dixon never really becomes a villain in this movie -- he even has a Rocky/Mickey relationship with his own trainer.

Also welcome are the numerous cable TV personality cameos.  Everyone from ESPN's Brian Kenny to ESPN Classic's Bert Randolph Sugar to the entire HBO fight team (Merchant and Lampley and I, Max) chips in; too bad Jim Rome got left on the cutting room floor.  The only thing missing from the celebrity bandwagon was Randy and Jason Sklar doing "Cheap Seats" commentary over the Rocky vs. Thunderlips celebrity boxing/wrestling match.  Maybe in a deleted scene on DVD?

In the end, "Rocky Balboa"'s a fun nostalgia trip that echoes the original in tone and sentiment, and even has a similar bittersweet finale.  This is never going to become a TNT rerun classic like "Rocky III" and probably has no catchphrases of its own, but if Rocky's been one of your movie heroes since the 1970s, check him out one last time.

I'm a big fan of the "Rocky" series, and I was very excited to see "Rocky Balboa." I didn't enjoy the film quite as much as I thought I would, but I still recommend it.

Here's the basic plot of the film: Rocky (Sylvester Stallone) has been running a small Italian restaurant in south Philadelphia for about ten years. His beloved wife Adrian (Talia Shire, who appears only in flashbacks of the other five "Rocky" movies) died of cancer three years ago. Rocky has been unable to let go of her, and the first 45 minutes of the movie basically outline the tremendous amount of grief he is feeling. In a way, Rocky is also grieving for his son (Milo Ventimiglia). Now a grown man, Rocky Jr. is unhappy with his job and has tried to distance himself from his father.

Rocky ultimately decides that he wants to try his hand at boxing again. He manages to acquire a license and plans to concentrate on small local fights. However, the current heavyweight champion, Mason Dixon (Antonio Tarver), becomes rattled after a televised computer matchup between him and Rocky deems Rocky as the winner. Mason invites Rocky to participate in an exhibition match, and Rocky accepts the offer.

Rocky's training doesn't go as smoothly as it did before: he's pushing 60 now and has to deal with arthritis, calcium deposits, and a variety of other ailments. As always, though, Rocky perseveres, and he gets a lot of help from his son and from good old Paulie (Burt Young). The film culminates in a Pay-Per-View matchup between Rocky and Mason in Las Vegas, which is as intense and emotional as every other fight we've seen in the series.

I won't spoil the ending for everyone, but I think the result of the fight was entirely appropriate. Once again, Rocky shows us the importance of fighting hard to keep our dreams alive, despite any obstacles that come our way. The film is very reminiscent of the first "Rocky" movie, and I really enjoyed that. There are also many flashbacks from the previous five films, and those old clips were a lot of fun to watch.

Even though I liked the movie, there were a few things I didn't care for. As I mentioned before, the first 45 minutes of the movie were incredibly depressing. Stallone obviously wanted us to focus on Rocky's character more than just the fighting itself, and I get that, but still...it was too darn depressing! Also, Rocky's friendship with Marie (Geraldine Hughes) was interesting at first because of the way she actually knows Rocky from years back, but I think the movie focused too much on their relationship. Marie did not have to be such a prominent fixture in the film. Finally, I didn't like the way most of the fight was filmed. It looked like we were watching an actual Pay-Per- View fight, which seemed very out of place with the rest of the movie's style. Stallone switched to using "regular" camera angles again at the very end of the fight, but I don't understand why he went with the whole HBO sports film sequence for so long.

Overall, I think Rocky fans will really enjoy this movie. It's very bittersweet, but it was nice to have a solid conclusion to the series. (And ANYTHING would have been better than "Rocky V!")

I just came from the opening showing of the film and a suprisingly packed house for a noon viewing!  I really enjoyed the film and the story...as well as Stallone's brilliant dialog.  This was the Rocky character we all fell in love with 30 years ago....and I really appreciated all the references to the history of the character and particularly the first installment. A very good bookend to the first ROCKY...I don't want to spoil it for others by discussing plotlines...just encourage fans of the first,  in particular, to get off their butts and to the theatre....it would be good for this to succeed and shut up all the big mouths and naysayers who want this character to go away.

Just got back from seeing this movie with my wife.  It was the first movie I'd gone to the theater to see in years.  I've watched all of the previous Rocky movies and enjoyed them all.  This one was no different.  I think they did a good job of not trying to be so serious about everything.  After the movie was over my wife said "Eh, it was a Rocky movie."  I guess that's how most people who aren't "Rocky fans" would rate it.  I really enjoyed the movie and will get the DVD when it comes out and watch it again.  Makes me want to go hop on the treadmill and start lifting some weights.  You know, developing some "hurtin' bombs."  I doubt the movie will win any awards but am still glad I went to see it.  Rocky!  Rocky!  Rocky!

Before I saw this movie, I asked myself 'who will this movie appeal to?' For old folks (such as myself), this iteration of Rocky might make me realize just how old we both are  (not a pleasant thought). To the younger generation, it might make them wonder why this movie needed to be made at all. After seeing the film, there is still no answer to my question.

The film is classic 'Rocky'. There are the endearing qualities of Rocky the man (such as referring to a Jamaican as  `a European') as well as the typical character witticisms we've come to love over the last thirty years. There is also Rocky's fondness for a former boxer (Spider Rico) he once fought (but not near the character development we saw with Apollo Creed).

We see familiar faces and places, such as Adrian (in flashback) whom Rocky visits regularly at the cemetery, Bert Young (as Paulie), and of course, the steps of the Philadelphia Museum (the end credits were a nice touch). There's even a cameo by Mike Tyson. But for most of the film Rocky is bemoaning the departed Adrian. It is almost pathetic to watch him visit memorable sites they once shared, such as the ice rink, which is no longer there. Enough already.

The movie is replete with 'shadows'. Rocky--living in the shadow of his former greatness--reduced to reliving the stories of fights long past. Rocky's son--now an inept businessman--living in the shadow of his father's legend. And Rocky's new love interest (wonderfully played by Irish actress Geraldine Hughes whose Philly brogue hides her strong accent)--living in the shadow of Adrian, with a son old enough to soon make her a grandmother. (Has it really been this long?)

To summarize the plot, Rocky still has a 'something in his basement' to exorcise the beast within (presumably to fight again). Mason Dixon is an unpopular heavyweight champ who (again presumably) would benefit from a fight with Rocky, after a computer fight has the Rock knocking him out. And so, the stage is set: the 'up-and-coming' Dixon will battle 'has been', Rocky. The match is arranged as a glorified exhibition, and Rocky must prove that 'the heart is the last thing to go'.

We're left to wonder, however, how this young boxer has anything to gain when he has everything to lose--a point cogently made in the film. This plot flaw--along with the absolutely 'goes nowhere' love interest--seriously cripples the movie.

But what this movie really lacks is believability, and the build-up we've come to expect toward pulling for the Rock to upset an opponent we love to hate. Mason Dixon never convinces us that he truly wants to destroy Rocky, or that he is unable to do so when he finally gets the chance. (The writers obviously anticipated this credibility issue, and the fighter breaks his hand.) Also, this fighter creates nowhere near the fight anticipation Ivan Drago created in Rocky IV. There is simply no hate between the rivals, and even in the fight, we wonder who will win more than we really care.

In the end, (without giving it away) let's say Rocky is mercifully retired forever. To their credit, the writers did not create an unbelievable ending to an unbelievable movie. As much as many of us loved the old films, we could not help but cringe when the Rock finally bears his chest. He is old, wrinkled, and fat. This time he cannot make us believe he should be in that ring, much less make us believe he could survive what happens in it. In previous Rocky movies, the fight piqued our suspense, and the ending made us cheer. In this one, we are left to merely endure the fight, and simply wish it over so we can see what novelty ending the writers will provide us this time.

I loved the old 'Rocky's'. But like most fighters he stayed for one fight too many. This movie made me feel really old and tired. Mercifully, ran less than a couple of hours, and I will always have the old Rocky movies when I need inspiration rather than a spoon of Geritol.
Without going into alot of details about the movie, this was really a good story.  If you like the Rocky saga, you will definitely like this movie as well.  Good job Sly Stallone!!

If Stallone keeps making Rocky movies, I would pay money to see every last one of them: I am a huge fan of the series, and I am a huge fan of the idea of having the courage to pursue your dreams and to pursue what God created you to do.

When an ESPN computer fight shows Rocky Balboa knocking out current heavyweight title holder Mason "The Line" Dixon, something stirs Rocky deep inside, a need to do what he was created to do, a need to fight again. Everyone thinks he's nuts, except for faithful friend Little Marie, who tells him that "fighters fight."

An astute Amazon reviewer noted that there are a lot of shadows in this movie: Rocky is living in the shadow of his glory days, the son is living in the shadow of his father, Mason Dixon is living in Rocky's shadow, even Spider Rico is living in Rocky's shadow, and Little Marie is living in Adrian's shadow (there are also a lot of shadowy scenes in the film
(alleys and streetlight scenes).

In a sense, Rocky himself is living in Adrian's shadow, as he struggles to move on with his life without her.

Let me also say that the fight scenes were very realistic, it
definitely has the look and feel of an HBO PPV telecast. My favorite
line is when Lampley asks Larry Merchant why they are calling this
fight an exhibition and Merchant says "so they won't have to call it an
execution."

Yes, the movie pulls at your tear ducts: The movie begins with Rocky at the tomb of Adrian and ends with Rocky at the tomb of Adrian. On the anniversary of Adrian's passing, Rocky goes to all of their special places and visits with her. He even tells his grown son, "Don't forget to visit your mom."

And yes, there are plenty of nods to nostalgia and maybe even a bit of self-parody, but this movie definitely climbs off the canvas and achieves a cinematic victory. Rocky Balboa is a knockout!
Hey, Rock, I'm in your corner....it ain't over til its over!!! Thanks for the great Christmas present! Now go out there and kill da bum!

Saw it yesterday at a sneak preview showing.

Rocky Balboa is one of the most likable characters ever, so he's easy to root for in any situation. But in this installment, there is really nothing on the line.  He isn't fighting for anything.  The fight falls flat because of it.  Even if he gets his head smashed in, its expected.  If he beats the heavyweight champ, it's ridiculous.  Sort of a no-win.

The lack of Adrian was noticable and sad.  They try to fill the female void with a kid from his past who is now a single mother, but that relationship ultimately leads nowhere, despite being a very substantial portion of the film.

I got the sense in the theater, which was packed, that everyone was waiting to go nuts and get excited, as Rocky has made us all do in the past.  But that moment never came.

While Stallone looks great for a guy his age, Rocky looks slow, old, and ridiculous at times.  Had they done this movie 10-15 yrs ago, and made it the 5th and final installment, it probably would have done the series good.

Since the Rocky series began, they have been an inspiration to average Americans, who hope they can advance themselves in life. This latest version "Rocky Balboa," is especially inspirational for middle aged men and women. Many Americans have lost their jobs to downsizing or outsourcing. Perhaps some of them will be motivated by this film to endure their loss, make adjustments, and move on with their lives.  Val Belfiglio

Only gripes is a little too much "flashback" stuff during the first quarter of the film, but after that there's not much wrong with it.

This is an American classic. For its indomitable faith in the underlying goodness of the American people, it deserves to be in the American Film Institute's list of 'The 100 Best Dramas' and it should be shown to schoolchildren in every foreign country. It is a beautiful film and, to Mr. Stallone's enormous credit, there is not a single gun or knife or vicious encounter to be seen (even the obligatory closing fight, for all its invested energy, is more of a flamenco duel than a bruising assault). In fact, there is not even a villain to boo and hiss, such is the maturity of the writing; the closest thing to it is the fight promoters but they are shown as businessmen simply, and openly, brokering a deal that they think best for their client. This is an intensely humane film. Virtually every one of the characters is damaged in some way but is salvaged by the care of others, most obviously by the character of Rocky himself. Watching it, I was reminded at times of Capra's 'It's a Wonderful Life' but, whereas that film was often noisily over-acted and sentimental, this film is perfectly pitched; there certainly is sentiment but it is laconic and subdued, in a way that echoes Steinbeck. Further, on this evidence, Mr. Stallone is one of the most thoughtful and generous players in Hollywood; as writer, director, and lead actor, not only does he create this powerful, compelling and life-enhancing drama, he also treats his fellow players with such care and ensures every one of them has an extended chance to light up the screen. And what a joy to see the great Burt Young again! A masterful actor as, indeed, is Sylvester Stallone when given the right material. Yet, how I would love to see him write a novel (perhaps he has already?).
All the Rocky movies are my favorite of all time.
One of the all time best movies ever made! By far the best of the series!
